positive.review: Celeste really is what its about, Climbing a mountain... I picked this game up not knowing what it was. Not having much platforming experience I got it thinking it would be a light and fun game to play for a short bit. I quickly realized I was incorrect and had made a mistake, this game was not for me... but I was struck by one of the first things the game tells you "You can do this" like it knew most people would think this way. So I kept going, easy enough at first but rapidly I was slowed to a dragging pace. At some point in each chapter I would audibly say "There's no way" and would get off. Everytime the next day something would tell me to try again. So I would try, die, try, die, try, die hundreds or thousands of times but eventually I would make it, only to say the same thing the next level. I have played many souls & souls-like games and enjoy high difficulty but this game hits different. Its brutally hard and frustrating and annoying at times but also beautiful and amazing and incredibly rewarding. This game is a mountain. Its filled with walls, setbacks and false peaks but if keep going you will learn can something about yourself. So begin the climb, be persistent and stubborn, forget the failures and relish in the successes and remember  "You can do this".

This game... is fun, loads of fun for me. How I played 580 hours of a single player game I have no clue but I never want this fun, precise, and well designed platformer to end. This is a great game for the people who love bashing their head into a brick wall and seeing if it sticks.

This game has tested my will, my sleep and still everything about it is perfect. I beat all C-side and have done everything the game has to offer and still i wish i could go back to the first time i booted up the game not knowing what i was getting myself into. At the end of the day Celeste is a game i would recommended this game too everyone.

Celeste, in my opinion, is just the best game i've ever played, and I can say that after having gotten every achievement and +70 hours just on the base game (combined with my playthrough on the switch.) This game is amazing; it's a hard yet addicting plataformer game. For casual players, even the main story will make you fall in love with this game - The story is amazing. But if you love hard tight gameplay, or want to challenge yourself, then completing all the B, C sides and chapter 9 is something you won't regret (even though they're incredibly hard). I also thought I wasn't a mountain climber, but well... I guess that just goes to show how much I loved this experience.

 I couldn't recommend less this game to anyone, it is honestly my favorite game ever and it just has so much content to explore that you never get tired. There's also so many fun mods available if you ever want something different out of Celeste. 10/10. Just go play it already!

Everything about this game feels so finely tuned and purposeful; Every level, every stage, every story beat, and every visual. Quintessential in the land of modern day 2d platformers. 

You could recommend this to almost anybody and they‚Äôd find something to get out of it; casual audiences within the genre, speed runners, modders, perfectionists, try hards, anyone with even a passing interest in these types of games. 

It‚Äôs honestly astonishing how well Maddy Makes Games managed to refine and polish this game till it hit the levels it does in this final build. 

I recommend this game strongly, especially since it always goes on sale for like, a few bucks lol.

An absolutely incredible game in every aspect. Incredible music, beautiful pixel art, amazing story, and most importantly incredible gameplay. It feels so incredibly smooth to play, and the movement is polished to perfection. The base game (as in just the a-sides) is challenging but still very accessible - I truly believe that with time nearly every person on the planet can beat it (and for those who can't or don't have the patience to, assist mode is there and perfectly implemented!) - but for those who want to go further there is always the much harder challenges of the b&c-sides, along with of course the infamous chapter 9. The modding scene is also one of the best I've ever seen, I highly recommend trying mods out! Absolutely worth experiencing at the very least the base game! (also, for those whom the price might get in the way, it goes on sale quite often and usually has a steep discount, so wait for one of those!)

One of the best precision platformers i have ever played! You are playing a character that is having a physical and emotional journey while climbing the Celeste mountain. It is trying to give you interesting and meaningful concepts while climbing (e.g anxiety, mental health, self-doubt, self acceptance, depression etc) and the character is trying to face/accept/embrace them. The music was sooo beautiful and its difficulty was solid if you want to finish it casually. HOWEVER, the game gives you  the opportunity to play optional stages where their difficulty skyrockets a little bit because it focuses more on precision AND consistency. One last thing..... a lot of stages will be challenging but none of them are speedrunning/frame perfect ones. In other words, no matter the deaths, keep trying and you will make it. This is what celeste is all about.

negative.review:
Ok, sure, this is a good game, and the team has put a ton of work in it. 
But it's still a PRECISION platformer. Which leads me to the core problem, and to Celeste special feature : "inclusivity" through the assist mode.

 I almost made it to the summit without assist mode, but then I reached the flag number 9, and there, everything went down the drain. I spent FOUR hours dying in repeat because I wanted to reach the end of the game in default mode, without assistance. But life is short, and I was starting to feel I was getting trolled. So yes, I switched to assisted mode... and passed the flag in 30 seconds. 

But once this was done, there were no turning back : I immediatly lost the taste for the challenge of the eight remaining flags, and stayed in assist mode to see the end. To me, it was "OK you cheated once, so the victory isn't your anymore". But than I felt super frustrated, because I was almost there without assistance, so I restarted Chaper 7 from scratch, without assistance, I fought my way back to this freaking flag 9. But, as I felt is was less a matter of skill than a matter of "know how", I watch a YT video to undertsand what I was doing wrong. Seems that, though I spent more than twenty hours on the game, this flag had a peculiar logic I wasn't able to guess. After the video, it took me like 10 minutes to get to flag 8. So, sure, as I'm editing this review, I "finished" Celeste. But I feel I didn't. And, as I had to watch a playthrough, I feel I never finished the game. The accomplishment isn't mine. Sure, at least the game showed me that I had the perseverance to 1/ try four hours long while being stuck 2/ redo the whole chapter to get things done the legit way. But in the end it left a very bitter taste in my mouth.

So, where am I going with this personal story ? I think that, for a game which pretend to be inclusive, benevolent, or whatever you wanna call it, a game which repeats you that "each death is a lesson," and that there's no shame to use the assist mode, it fails.

First, dying four hours in a row didn't teach me anything : I already knew how to open a freaking YouTube tab to watch a playthough. 

Second, if the game is so hardcore that I need an assist mode, it doesn't make me "accept" myself. It just makes me stuck in an impossible dilemma : losing hours of my life and feeling like s**it because I can reach the end by myself, or succumbing to the assist mode and feeling like I didn't earned to see the end in a noble way. 

Three : it's precision platformer, indeed, so it's not that much about reflexes and mecanichal skills then it is a matter of learning pattern by heart for long sections (like reach flag 2, with the feather). 

This said, the game has great pixel art, OK from great music (not my favorite type of chiptune, especially when I'm stuck four hours with the same track but some of the quietest tracks are really beautifull) and a real artistic vision. The game masters storytelling by gameplay. Its flaw is its paradoxical, almost double bind, approach to self-care. Maybe the Dark Souls ways better : the series assume that you had to get good enough, and if not, yu can stillenjoy the lore and the graphics by watching let's plays. 

Maybe it's for you, and it got critical acclaim anymay, but for me the whole Flag 9 bulls**t ruined the whole experience.

I got lost at some point, as it wasn‚Äôt clear what exactly I was supposed to do. I expected a fun mechanical challenge, but instead I found complex navigation. Overall, it felt much less dynamic and entertaining than other games in the same genre.

Here's the thing: I love the game, the story is great, and the platforming is fluid, but there are constant crashes, to the point where it is basically unplayable. It has crashed upwards of 20 times so far, and I estimate that I have lost 3+ hours of gameplay because of it.

Right off the bat, the controls are just absolutely awful. You can remap them, but as a native KBM player - not being able to map the mouse to anything is a big glaring black mark - as its reflexively more comfortable than forcing my right hand to use keyboard controls. The controller isn't quite as bad, but playing on joystick makes any diagonal mechanics a nightmare because of stick sensitivity. The jump after dash and diagonal dashing (specifically diagonal-down) does not seem to consistently work making it feel like the controls are constantly fighting me. Its a precision platformer, adjust expectations right? I get it - yeah yeah- just get good... I love platformers and the precision ones, while they give me hell - I usually love them... but I just cant be bothered. At only 3 hours in - I am already not having fun with this. I expect many deaths, I expect having to try a lot and fail a lot. But I feel like them adding 'accessibility mode' to the game, where you can turn off all the mechanics with infinite dashing, god mode, etc... they are aware of the flaws, and just said "Oh please play our game, we will let you cheat!" Additionally, Why cant you look around the immediate level to plan the route? I really don't think that it would take anything from the gameplay allowing the player to plan a few steps ahead of them. You'd still have to fail plenty while training the coordination to carry out the path.

I just can't recommend this with the terrible controls, the politically aligned plot, and the dismissive "accessibility". Ok, sure, this is a good game, and the team has put a ton of work in it. 
But it's still a PRECISION platformer. Which leads me to the core problem, and to Celeste special feature : "inclusivity" through the assist mode.

 I almost made it to the summit without assist mode, but then I reached the flag number 9, and there, everything went down the drain. I spent FOUR hours dying in repeat because I wanted to reach the end of the game in default mode, without assistance. But life is short, and I was starting to feel I was getting trolled. So yes, I switched to assisted mode... and passed the flag in 30 seconds. 

But once this was done, there were no turning back : I immediatly lost the taste for the challenge of the eight remaining flags, and stayed in assist mode to see the end. To me, it was "OK you cheated once, so the victory isn't your anymore". But than I felt super frustrated, because I was almost there without assistance, so I restarted Chaper 7 from scratch, without assistance, I fought my way back to this freaking flag 9. But, as I felt is was less a matter of skill than a matter of "know how", I watch a YT video to undertsand what I was doing wrong. Seems that, though I spent more than twenty hours on the game, this flag had a peculiar logic I wasn't able to guess. After the video, it took me like 10 minutes to get to flag 8. So, sure, as I'm editing this review, I "finished" Celeste. But I feel I didn't. And, as I had to watch a playthrough, I feel I never finished the game. The accomplishment isn't mine. Sure, at least the game showed me that I had the perseverance to 1/ try four hours long while being stuck 2/ redo the whole chapter to get things done the legit way. But in the end it left a very bitter taste in my mouth.

So, where am I going with this personal story ? I think that, for a game which pretend to be inclusive, benevolent, or whatever you wanna call it, a game which repeats you that "each death is a lesson," and that there's no shame to use the assist mode, it fails.

First, dying four hours in a row didn't teach me anything : I already knew how to open a freaking YouTube tab to watch a playthough. 

Second, if the game is so hardcore that I need an assist mode, it doesn't make me "accept" myself. It just makes me stuck in an impossible dilemma : losing hours of my life and feeling like s**it because I can reach the end by myself, or succumbing to the assist mode and feeling like I didn't earned to see the end in a noble way. 

Three : it's precision platformer, indeed, so it's not that much about reflexes and mecanichal skills then it is a matter of learning pattern by heart for long sections (like reach flag 2, with the feather). 

This said, the game has great pixel art, OK from great music (not my favorite type of chiptune, especially when I'm stuck four hours with the same track but some of the quietest tracks are really beautifull) and a real artistic vision. The game masters storytelling by gameplay. Its flaw is its paradoxical, almost double bind, approach to self-care. Maybe the Dark Souls ways better : the series assume that you had to get good enough, and if not, yu can stillenjoy the lore and the graphics by watching let's plays. 

Maybe it's for you, and it got critical acclaim anymay, but for me the whole Flag 9 bulls**t ruined the whole experience.

This game reminded me why I hate precision platformers.

I really wanted to love Celeste. Everyone raves about it... the touching story about mental health, the beautiful pixel art, the soundtrack that's supposedly transcendent. I can see why people connect with Madeline's journey. The anxiety metaphors are thoughtful, the presentation is polished, and there's clearly a lot of heart poured into this game. But no amount of narrative depth can make me enjoy dying 47 times on the same screen because I mistimed a dash by 0.2 seconds.

Precision platformers demand a very specific kind of patience and muscle memory that I simply don't find enjoyable. Every death in Celeste is supposedly a "lesson," and yes, the respawns are lightning-fast, but that doesn't change the fundamental loop: attempt, fail, repeat ad nauseam until your fingers finally cooperate with your brain. It's not that the game is unfair - the controls are tight, the mechanics are clear - it's that this style of gameplay brings out the worst in me. The mounting frustration. The clenched jaw. The "just one more try" that turns into an hour of my life I'll never get back.

The game keeps telling me to "just breathe" while simultaneously designing situations that make me want to throw my controller through a window. There's something almost patronizing about a game that says "you can do this!" while putting strawberries just out of reach, taunting you with collectibles that require frame-perfect execution.

I understand why Celeste resonates with so many people. The metaphor of climbing a mountain as overcoming your inner demons is powerful. But sometimes a mountain is just a mountain, and sometimes I just want to enjoy a game without feeling like I'm studying for a reflex exam.

If you love precision platformers, you'll probably adore this. If you're like me and this genre makes you question your life choices, maybe skip this one.
